Pours an opaque black color with a brown head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, oak, and sweet scotch.  Flavor is malty, caramel, oak, vanilla, and a dry scotch finish.
Bottled @ Aarhus beerfestival 2008. Lovely aroma of roasted malt, peat, hint of medicine, coffee and licorice. Very malty taste, almost sour, oak, loads of peat, bit sweet. Great stuff.
750ml swing-top bottle.  Pours a dark brown /  black,  dark brown head.  Aromas of fresh peat, chocolate, hints of butterscotch.  Flavor is a bit of roast, chocolate,some oak, lots of peat.
At Arhusbeerfestival.Dark brownish colour with no head.Aroma is smoked and warming with strong hidden alc.Some taste of vanilla and spices full body and well balanced finish.

Shared by Reakt/Mes. Probably getting shorted compared to the rest of the beasts that we tried that night, but oh well. Some fruit and chocolate, alcohol was a bit too noticable. Would do very well with some age on it. Pretty good beer for being from a place with a made up name. (thanks Sim)

750 ml bottle - thanks to after4ever for sharing this; thick, dark brown with thin off-white head; texture is thick and creamy; just a kick as nose of chocolate, sweet candy and caramel; creamy and chewy body; definitively boozy and dumps a slight burn on you, but this has a deep richness to it; Oradian Ale is a new term to me; just delish; thanks tom!!

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Bottle, bought @ Skjold Burne, Store Torv, Århus, Denmark.
Pitch black with a small, beige, film head. Rather creamy. Aroma is lightly fruity tart, heavily peity with a dose of chocolate. Low carbonation, very fat mouthfeel, nice oiliness. Flavour is initially tart, lots of dried fruits, good dose of dark chocolate, good roastiness. Wonderful, long aftertaste of peity smoke and light wood.

(bottle, thanks Badgerben) Pours brown with a cream colored head.  Aroma has a lot of smoke, and not too much else.  The taste is also smoky as well with some light vanilla, and a lingering smoky finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Not an overly complex beer, but it was still very good.

Thanks for sharing this one Todd.  Nov 10., 2007 bottling.  The beer pours to a black body with a creamy tan head.  The aroma is peaty as hell.  Some notes of red delicious apples amongst all the peat smoked wood.  The flavor is a rich peat malt, sweet oaken apples, chocolate, and molasses.  The are complex but not really old-ale-ish.  Rich palate that finishes thick and boozy with a long sugary finish.

[bottle] shared by badgerben. Poured black with no head. Huge aroma. Roasty and sweet, with some chocolate and peat. Flavor is peat smoked malt, vanilla, some subdued scotch whisky, and some alcohol in there as well. Very good beer.

[Bottle, thanks Badgerben!] Pours black with a tan head. The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, peat and whiskey.  The taste is has a lot of smoke, peat, and alcohol. Roasted malt definitely is in there as well, especially towards the finish. Medium mouthfeel with a long finish. As Ben said, this is really an unusual barley wine, but it was a good beer.

Bottled November 10, 2007.  Black color with a thin head.  Big peaty aroma.  Lots of whisky and sherry.  Chocolate.  The taste is somehow not dominated by peat, but it is screaming peat.  Oak and vanilla, sweet malt and honey.  Very little hop bitterness, but it is there.  I dont think this is really a barley wine, but it is delicious.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Thin, oily, charred oak pour.  Fairly faint and basic chocolate and scotch whiskey aroma; grahams, honey, lots of smoky peat.  A really pleasant and warming campfire kind of aroma.  Bit of red wine, and nougat fills out the detailed sweetness evident here.  Flavor is cool and oily with a big, but laid back scotch flavor; lots of wildflower honey, green apple, nougat and cinnamon whipped cream.  Alcohol deftly understated.  Palate is thoroughly soft and feathery; a really erudite and finely polished texture.  Not dense, but glassy and deep.  Long, generous creme brulee finish.  Heat is there, but it doesnt damage the flavors of the malt but more comes across as it does in the whiskey itself.  Likeable.  Thanks for sharing, Ben!

750ml bottle. shared by tytoanderso at An Evening with Pantanap #4.   Pours black with a brown head.  Nose of chocolate, alcohol, and sweet malts.  Sweet and boozy flavors.  Chocolate, brown sugar, green apple, and alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2008 Big thanks to Badgerben for sharing this rare and expensive beer.  The aroma is nice, peat, smoke, and malt with very light spice.  A black beer and no carbonation.  Exceptionally complex flavor.  Peat, seasalt, smoke, malt, and oak that imparts a wood, and vanilla flavor.   The high abv is well hidden and not noticeable in the aroma or flavor.

750 ml bottle.  Shared with the Chi-Town crew at P4.  Left my tasting notes there, so these are transcribed by Kan from my chicken scratch and then BMed back to me. Aroma of boozy whiskey, wood and thicker malt. Fairly faint though. Pours a thick, nearly lifeless dark brown with no head. Flavor of green apple skin, chewy toffee malt, wet wood and a heavy whiskey presence. 
Lush and creamy on the tongue. Very carbonated with a hot boozy finish. This a very boozy beer.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 1st edition. Black of color with a nice brown head. A roasted aroma with malty, coffee, whisky and liqurice notes. A flavor with prunes, liqurice, roasted and weak smoked notes. 6-4-7-3-14.

2nd edition. Black of color with a creamy brown head. An aroma of burnt malt, whisky, roasted and chocolate hints. A flavor of liqurice, smoke and burnt.
This is a very tasty brew. complex flavors that are nicely complemented by the whisky barrel aging.

750ml bottle. shared by tytoanderso at An Evening with Pantanap #4. pours black with tan head. nose is green apple, wood, some chocolate. flavor of green apple, alcohol, bakers chocolate, some espresso. this is a barleywine? taste and looks more like a stout. the green apple and over barrel aging hurts this beer.

bottle thanks to tyler who brought this for the latest P tasting.... pours a dark brown with brown edges with very little head ......aroma of some sour apple, whiskey, and soy..... a lot of that sour apple comes through in the flavor with a big boozy whiskey factor as well.  somewhat boozy

Bottle big, big thanks to Craig, cgarvieuk for getting this for me, cheers mate! Had this 03-04-08   Pours shark eye black looks like a bottomless pit or grimping mire, Stephen Hawkins has written books on things that arent as black as this, even the tan head seemed to cling to the side of the glass desperately trying to avoid being sucked into the black void. Aroma of vanilla, some light whisky and also woody. Bitter orange on the first sip and noticeable in the fact that this lacks the sweetness of many of its ilk. Quite drying at times and the bitterness forces its way back through, a slow drinker especially if you have it all to yourself save for 125ml that I gave to Lozs dad. I liked this beer, very tasty and most enjoyable.

Bottled at RBESG 2007. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet and acidic with strong notes of whiskey and wood. The flavor is sweet with a powerful note of whiskey as well as brettanomyces which lends it an acidity, but also medium notes of alcohol, prunes, and wood, as well as hints of salt.
Moderate malty aroma with rasin notes. Small, light brown head. Black body. Heavy bitter flavor. Medium palate.

750 ml bottle, shared by after4ever on 3/20/08 with hogfodder and myself.  Bottled on November 10, 2007 according to the label. Pour is deep brown almost black with a slight off white head. Head fades quickly.  Aroma of the whisky and wood primarily with malt caramel very quickly behind. Taste reflects the nose nicely, with some booziness.  This was a very in your face beer, though well made and quite tasty.

At the BBB63 comes to Tampa gathering, thanks to our host DeGarth and his brother DeWayne, party on!  Nearly opaque with a small head and some clinging lace, a bit oily as well. The aroma has a big wonderful character of molasses, plum, earth, peat, tobacco, oak barrel, clove and a hint only of whiskey. The taste is quite weird, slightly oxidized and woody with a fruity and earthy tone, A neato spicy and vinous finish. The mouth feel i oily and heavy, soft and woody dry upon the finish. This was really nice and quite enjoyable, my favorite of the night! The sum is more than the parts IMO.
Bottle. Black colour with dark brown fully diminishing head. Aroma is roasted malt. Spicy flavor. Creamy palate.
Thank to Myrup. Black colour with a littl eheaad. Smooth great aroma of whisey, roastedness and sweet malt. Nice flavour of whiskey, malt, roastedness. Very tasty and smooth, areally great beer.

Courtesy Degarth.  Nice looking bottle, first off.  Dark chestnut pour, thin sparse white head.  Sweet caramel malts, plum, molasses, a very English aroma, reminds me of the Fullers Vintage ales.  Sweet dark canesugary taste, but kept in check.  Plums, oak, tobacco, mild English hops all on the taste.  Everything melds perfectly and this was one of my favorites from the Tampa tasting.

750, swingtop. Black. Thick (though shallow) creamy tan head. Huge coffee, roasty nose--along with port, and red wine grapes. Rich creamy, oily body. Tawny port, raisins, figs, bourbon, roast, and coffee on the mid-palate. Long cocoa finish. Indescribably delicious, much more than the sum of its flavor parts. So much happening with the brewing...there must be a dozen specialty malts in here.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown fair mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty powerfull aroma. Strong rasin notes. Very spicey complex flavor. Long nice finish. Very creamy palate. Great stuff but expensive.

Cleveland tasting
Once again an amazing brew was cracked open.  I am going to have to start doing some serious trading to have something worthwhile to contribute to these tastings as I dont know how people find these rarities.  Actually in this case I do as it just hit Ohio according to someone.  If you run across this in the store dont hesitate to put it in your cart.
Aroma / Appearance - The fluid black body was darker than I expected a barley wine to be.  Whiskey, malt and oily scents stand out though there is also resiny burnt pine providing a solid foundation.
Flavor / Palate - Blue raspberries blended into iced coffee form a very strange partnership.  Oily and slightly stale hops unfold before the vinuous warm finish.  The alcohol is evident but does not ruin the experience.  Overall this is a very solid release.
Beautiful dark brown color with very dark tanned head. Burnt malt flavor and a lot of vinegar.
Strong fluid raisin. Very good straight beer. The absence of head odsent disturb because its so clean fluid...
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small beige creamy head. Powerful malty aroma with notes of raisin and viniger. Flavour of caramel, fruits and spice. Nice full palate.
Bottled 20th of March 2006. Small head with short duration. Color is pitch black. Aroma and taste are fruits, wood, caramel and vinegar. Sour long finish.

Rating #1300Huge thanks to Degarth for opening this much anticipated brew. Pours deep dark brown with dark tan head. The aroma is simply huge and inviting. I get sweet rich Concord grapes in high volume along with earthiness, faint peat, dark roasted malts, faint dark chocolate and a mild, yet building, sense of alcohol. The taste is very similar to the nose with caramel candy, earthiness, mild peat that slowly turns into sweet rich ripe dark fruitiness of dark grapes, prunes and sweet plums. I also get notes of fudge brownies, moderate booze sensation and wood. Some mild acidity lingers into the after taste along with layers of roasty  earthy  dark fruity notes.

Courtesy of Degarth. Thank you, sir.

Dark brown/cola body....small head, resolves to a swirly mix of bubbles and foam....dark fruit esters, yeast, chocolate, peat and oak....flavor profile similar, mainly focused on the barrel aged notes and chocolate, with a sweet malty presence....the peaty/smoky notes pick up along the way through the back of the beer....medium bodied, lush and clings to the tongue....finish is sublime, peat and sweet notes mix wonderfully with the earthiness from the barrels....outstanding....

Bottle... March 08 Tampa Bay Tasting... This beer rocks!... Murky, practically black ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Great retention. The aroma provides rich notes of chocolate, cashews, pistachios, subtle wood, peat and light, creamy diacetyl. Full-bodied with a melted butter mouthfeel and pillow-soft carbonation. The woodsy, lightly acidic flavor also offers bittersweet chocolate, mild bitterness and subtle alcohol heat. Finishes earthy with tangy whiskey and oak. Bottle provided by Degarth. Thanks, Joe!

[Courtesy of Myrup, tasting @ Ølbaren] Dark brown with tiny head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, ripe fruits and.oak Sweet flavor with roasted malt, whisky, overripe fruit, oak and smoky notes. Delicious.

Courtesy Degarth.  POurs a murky dark brown, with a small swirly light brown head.  Smells pretty sweet, dark fruits andmalts reign supreme in the nose.  The flavor is smooth as all hell.  Some light tartness was apparent, with the grapes, light peat, and sweet maltiness rounding out its smooth silky flavors.  Very easy drinking brew, and very balanced and flavorful.  Really enjoyed this brew.

Tasting at Ølbaren 2008.03.11 - Thanks Myrup for sharing. I have a bottle of this in my cellar, and I look forward to maturing it furthermore. Its black/brown with notes of oak, roasted malt and raisin in the aroma. The flavour has sweetness, raisin, licorice, caramel, dark fruits and the finish is quite roasted bitter - but also pleasantly sweetish. Its a harmonic and nice beer, and I look forward to re-tasting it!

Bottle. [Courtesy of Myrup] Small fizzy beige head that mostly diminished. Spare lacework. Pitch black color. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, liquorish, vanilla, roasted malt. Full bodied with an average carbonation and thick light alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet with counter bitterness in the flavor. Lingering alcoholic and chocolate finish.

75 cL bottle, thanks to Myrup. Pours dark brown to black with a lacing tan head. Vanilla, liqourice and roasted malt. Flavour is roasted malt, tar like and woody with a little sweetness and a solid liqourice note. Lingering liqourice and light vanilla finish.

Pitch black, tan creamy head.  Intense aromas of cocoa wood and peat smoke that layer over warm whiskey soaked dark fruits and touches of vanilla.  Smooth oaked fig and prune flavors balance on smoked vanilla  notes and hints of dark chocolate.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish.  The highlight beer for me on this night.  Thanks for sharing,  jeffin7!

Bottle. Pours thick, pitch black with a big, brown head. Intense aroma; In the vicinity of the glass its sweet and fruity with roasted and oak notes. In the glass its sweetnsour and dry with notes of fruit, chocolate and caramel. Flavour is sour and fruity with notes of filled chocolate, alcohol and plums. Very complex and full-bodied. A bit difficult to drink  could only take sips. Actually a bit cloying in the long run, but still some intense beer. Would love to cellar it. 24-01-08.

(75cl bottle, thanks jeffin7) Brown-black body with small tan head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, some whisky/vanilla, plum/raisin.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, whisky/vanilla, some smoke/peat, raisin, light caramel.  Medium-full body with low carbonation and some stickiness.

Pours with nearly no head atop a brown body with red light at the edge of the liquid.  Super, super sweet maple and whisky nose, I guess it’s a little cold at first, because the aroma develops significantly over time, eventually turning less sweet and more approachable – amaretto and almonds mixed with burnt, nutty maple, mixed with some chewy caramel malt base to the barley wine/strong ale that’s beneath this massive infusion of sweet whisky.  But, for all the faults I could find in the smell, none of them mattered much because of the just absolutely amazing flavor that develops in the finish… up front it’s on the sweet side, and then over the middle a little more of the true whisky and wood flavors are first noticed, right before an amazingly rich and decadent bitter cocoa and chocolate flavor coast the tongue, along with a soothing flavor of dried prunes, raisins, some nuts, and some coffee.  Really, exceptionally complex in the finish, and I really with the aroma and initial flavor were as stellar.

75cL bottle, courtesy of jeffin7.  Thanks, Jeff!  Pours a very dark, oily cola color; light tan head that fades rather quickly.  Very generous, peat-driven aroma: loads of bitter chocolate, intricate whiskey notes (peaty, oiliness, wood), slightly charred and burnt; very aromatic and whiskey-forward.  Very light carbonation.  Full, intense bitter and dark chocolate in the mouthfeel: whiskey presence has very soft edges; integrated nicely with tons of dried dark fruits and a bitter chocolate / cocoa core.  Tasty stuff, well blended.  Lengthy finish, showing dry chocolate, cocoa, and a touch of lingering whiskey.

Rating #1400. Dark brown body with a tiny tan head. The nose is lightly sweet with roast, dark chocolate and brown sugar. The flavor is fairly sweet, very light bitterness with chocolate, molasses, prunes, figs and roast. Full body is soft with light carbonation.

Thanks Boboski!!!  Pours a nearly opaque black.  Aroma is intoxicating melange of vanilla, marshmallow, wisps of smoke and wood, some chocolate, peat and seaweed.  The flavor is a touch boozy, yet it seems to work perfectly in this beer.  The smoke note really makes its presence known here.  Incredible beer.

Bottle. Brown but very quickly disappearing head. Looking through the glass and into my sharp lamp I can see some ruby nuances at the bottom. Without a lamp I would definately call it pitch black. Putting my nose close to this fuidum makes me in doubt about what is actually in the glass as it is very vineous, coffee, cocoa, prunes and plums and a good deal of alcohol. Flavor though is beer not wine, thank God. Still coffee, cocoa prunes, plums and maybe even raisins. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.  If it is the long storage in oak barrels I do not know but the high alcohol contents is very well hidden and the beer appears smooth, round, pleasant and what else I can use of positive words. Very good, expensive though.

Bottle. Pours an almost black color with a small brown head. Aroma of malt raisins, dark fruit and oak. Also some weak aroma of chocolate. Has a slightly roasted malty oak flavor with lots of dark fruit and chocolate. Also a little vinous hints. Warming roasted malty finish with hints of dark fruit.

Last bottle at Stone World Bistro for $42.  This is the Extraordinary Orcadian Ale with the swing top at 10%...ayieee!  Black, swirling brown head.  Big aroma of Scotch, oak, roasted malts, subtle cane syrup and smoke.  Smooth yet big flavor of an oak aged liquor barrel.  "Fruit, spices, oak and roast malt" is what the bottle says.  It also suggests food pairing with pate, red meat dishes, dark chocolate and strong cheeses.  Warmed up theres some sour oak barrel notes, bitter chocolate, scotch.  The big aroma remains till the end...lovely!

For rate number 2,000, sampled from 750 ml bottle and shared by brewfiend. Pours a cloudy dark brown brew with a thick tan head that has some good retention. Aroma of milk chocolate, raisins, dark pitted fruit, orange zest, and a touch of coffee. Taste is full bodied, lightly syrupy, with flavors of smoked roasted dark malt, raisins, some oak wood, and caramel. Finish is semi-sweet with a lingering mild bitterness after the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2010 First rating75 bottle at Bishops Arms, V Hamng, Göteborg Bottled 2006Shared with ekstedt, Marsiblursi and a non-ratebeer friend.Pitch black color, small brown head. Acidic, malty, raissin, oak and wood scent. Also alochol. Sweet malt, oak, raissin and acidic taste. Oak and roasted aftertaste. Some smoke in the taste. Feels dry once the acidic main part of teh taste settles a bit. Not worth the 55 we paid for it. Might be too oxidized or perhaps in infection? Did not deliver what I had expected.7/4/6/4/13=3.4RerateShared bottle at Haket on November 13, 2010, during SÖ 25 year anniversaryBlack color, brown head. Sweet, licorice, chocolate scent. Sweet, cocoa, milk chocolate taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/6/3/13=3.2

Bottle (75 cl) at Bishops Arms, V Hamngatan, Göteborg, Sweden, shared with gnoff, marsiblursi and non-RB Mikael. Deep black with a thin beige head. Raisiny, fruity and vinous with notes of wood and oranges, and some light burnt and roasted notes. Medium bodied and silky smooth. Some sweetness backed up by a moderate acidity and bitterness.

Bottle at Bjergtrolden.

Mostly lasting light tan head covers the deep Bordeaux-brown shade. The scotch certainly comes up in here. Alcohol remains well contained in the nose though. Tar, oil, peat and generally fat malts make up for the aroma profile. Its body is thick and punctuated solely by very soft carbonation. Rather disturbing mouth experience though, it displays the 4 basic flavours in spades and surprisingly, the unusual sourness and saltiness might be the dominating ones. Other beers like Orval can reach the 4 basic flavours as well, but not by focusing on sour and salt, its tremendous dryness saves Orval and throws it in mythic territory. Here, the beer feels more mineral than hoppy. I dont deny its grand complexity, but I find it chaotic and the sour/salty combo is honestly out of place in this peaty, molasses oriented rich ale that does not deserve to be so easily linked to soy sauce.
